course.title: Mexico: Revolution, Authoritarianism and Democracy: 100 Years
course.description: Mexico over the past century experienced a prolonged violent revolutionary war and subsequent transformation, established one of the world's longest-lived authoritarian regimes, and has been building robust democratic politics. The combination of these three dramatic moments is rare worldwide. Most countries in that century had only one or two such moments. Why did Mexicans kill each other so relentlessly for so long? Why did they build, from the rulers' perspective, the world's most effective authoritarian regime? Why was democratic transition so slow-moving? Was there collective wisdom in democratic politics, steering a successful transition within the lifetimes of the Freshmen?
